nodes.text: Under random multiplicative income dynamics the ensemble-average growth rate (GDP per capita) exceeds the time-average growth rate (DDP per capita); this difference (ergodicity gap) quantifies inequality and reporting both rates would better inform policy
Ensemble-average growth rate is the growth rate of average income (GDP per capita) and is approximately an income-weighted (plutocratic) average of individual growth rates

Time-average growth rate equals the long-time growth rate experienced by an individual and can be computed as the growth rate of the geometric mean income (DDP per capita); it is a democratically weighted average of individual growth rates

The difference between ensemble-average and time-average growth rates (ergodicity gap) grows when inequality increases and corresponds under multiplicative dynamics to the mean logarithmic deviation (MLD), a known inequality metric
The time-average growth rate and the ergodicity gap depend only on initial and terminal income distributions and are independent of rank mobility between observations

Method: model incomes with random multiplicative growth (Gibrat law), mathematically transform incomes by logarithm to obtain ergodic growth rates, and analyze both general theory and the special case of geometric Brownian motion (GBM); estimate statistics from cross-sectional quantile data

Result (analytic, GBM): ensemble-average growth rate equals mu, time-average growth rate equals mu minus sigma squared over two, so ensemble-average exceeds time-average by sigma squared over two and ergodicity gap grows linearly in time
Empirical claim: In US data since 1980 GDP per capita (ensemble-average) grew substantially faster than DDP per capita (time-average), whereas in France the two rates remained much closer

Policy claim: National statistical authorities should compile and report ensemble-average (GDP per capita), time-average (DDP per capita), and the ergodicity gap (MLD) to avoid misleading impressions of typical individual experience

Evidence: simulations and analytic results show for realistic population sizes and volatilities finite-N estimates of ensemble and time-average growth rates concentrate near their theoretical values, implying relevance for real national populations

Method/Evidence: time-average growth rate and DDP per capita can be estimated from cross-sectional quantile averages (geometric mean of incomes) without panel data; validation shows percentile-based estimates are stable

Limitation: DDP per capita (geometric mean) is sensitive to low-income measurement and requires positive incomes; practical estimations may truncate bottom tail (authors use bottom decile truncation) which affects quantitative values though not qualitative conclusions

Conclusion: The conceptual distinction between ensemble-average and time-average growth rates is important empirically and politically; when ensemble-average growth outpaces time-average growth it signals rising inequality and potential political disconnect between policymakers and typical citizens
